importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the conclusion of the ALCS and the Blue Jays' advancement to the World Series, marking a pivotal moment in the 2025 MLB postseason.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time of update reflects the immediacy and live nature of the sports news, emphasizing the real-time excitement of the game's outcome.

keyTakeAways: George Springer's three-run home run in the seventh inning turned the tide of the ALCS Game 7, leading the Toronto Blue Jays to a 4-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners.
The Blue Jays are headed to their first World Series since 1993, marking a significant milestone in the franchise's history.
The game featured controversy involving umpiring decisions, including a disputed call on Jorge Polanco's base run due to a ricocheting throw off Naylor's helmet.
Vladimir Guerrero Jr. was named ALCS MVP after a stellar performance, batting .385 and hitting three home runs during the series.
The Blue Jays will host the Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, pitting the AL’s best team against the defending champion.
The Seattle Mariners, despite a strong start and multiple home runs, remain the only MLB franchise never to have appeared in a World Series, adding historical context to their loss.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer delivered a decisive three-run home run in the seventh inning, directly leading to the Blue Jays' victory and their advancement to the World Series.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays won the ALCS, securing their spot in the World Series and marking a historic milestone as the franchise's first appearance since 1993.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners lost in Game 7 of the ALCS, remaining the only MLB team never to have reached a World Series, and thus their defeat is historically significant.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Dodgers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dodgers are the defending champions and the eventual opponent in the World Series, creating a high-stakes matchup that draws global attention.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Guerrero Jr. was named ALCS MVP for his outstanding performance, including three home runs and a .385 batting average, highlighting the team’s offensive strength.

namedEntities.name: Julio Rodriguez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rodriguez hit multiple home runs during the series, including a solo shot in the third inning and a key offensive contribution in the early innings.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh, a regular-season home run leader, hit five long balls in the playoffs, including four against the Blue Jays, contributing to the Mariners' offensive push.

namedEntities.name: Eduardo Bazardo
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bazardo was the pitcher facing George Springer in the crucial seventh inning at-bat, where the game-winning home run was hit.

namedEntities.name: Shane Bieber
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bieber pitched for the Mariners, and Rodriguez hit a solo home run off him in the third inning, a pivotal moment in the game's progression.

namedEntities.name: Daulton Varsho
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Varsho drove in a run with a soft ground ball in the bottom of the first inning, helping tie the game early.

namedEntities.name: Jorge Polanco
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Polanco's ground ball led to a controversial call involving Ernie Clement and Naylor, impacting the flow of the game and creating a pivotal moment in the first inning.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement made a key play in the first inning where his throw ricocheted off Naylor's helmet, resulting in a disputed call that influenced the game's momentum.

namedEntities.name: Chris Bassitt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bassitt pitched a scoreless eighth inning, contributing to the Blue Jays' successful defensive performance in the later innings.

namedEntities.name: Jeff Hoffman
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hoffman pitched a perfect ninth inning to close out the game and secure the Blue Jays’ victory.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Toronto Blue Jays advanced to their first World Series since 1993 after defeating the Seattle Mariners 4-3 in a dramatic ALCS Game 7. George Springer’s three-run home run in the seventh inning turned the game around, ending a tense and controversial matchup that saw early offensive bursts and a disputed play involving Ernie Clement and Josh Naylor. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. was named ALCS MVP for his outstanding performance. Despite the Mariners' early leads and several home runs, they remain the only MLB franchise never to reach a World Series. The Blue Jays will now face the defending champion Los Angeles Dodgers in the World Series, marking a historic moment for the franchise and a high-stakes showdown for fans around the world.
title: George Springer’s epic home run helps send the Toronto Blue Jays to the World Series with ALCS Game 7 win over Seattle
